page.title: 03Inchmickery - bird life
page.content:
The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, who own the landing rights to the island, which is uninhabited. The R.S.P.B. do a regular bird count on Inchmickery as the rather rare {Roseate Tern}breeds here after wintering in Gambia. There they are caught by small boys with hooked lines.
To protect these particular terns the gulls are culled. The number of terns is slowly inreasing with 4 pairs recorded in 1984 and 9 pairs in 1985.
Other birds recorded are Sandwich Terns, Common Terns, Fulmar, Shag, Eider, Mallard, Shelduck, Oyster Duck and Feral Pigeon. The island is on the north/south migrant route and there is also drift from Europe and so sometimes rare migrants appear.
